This is the Quickstart guide for using a pre-compiled binary distribution of CloudCoder.

Please note that the binary distributions currently have some weaknesses:

  • No SSL connections to the CloudCoder server (unless you configure apache and configure a reverse-proxy)

Servers

Ideally, you need 2 servers: One for the CloudCoder server (the Webapp), and one for the CloudCoder builder service (the Builder). Under heavier loads, you can provision more machines to run additional Builders.

You need a MySQL database on the server, and will need JDK 1.6 or higher, gcc/g++ if you plan to use C/C++ exercises on the webapp server and all builder servers.

While we don’t recommend it for a production environment, you can run both the webapp and the builder on one machine (useful if you want to try out the software yourself, or if you are brave and have very small class sizes).

CloudCoder has only been tested under Linux (Ubuntu) and Mac OS 10.7. It may run on other versions of Unix, though it has not been tested. It will probably not run on Windows.

Step 1: Configure MySQL

You need to set up a MySQL database on the server hosting the webapp.

You must know the following pieces of information used to connect to your MySQL server:

  • username (cloudcoder is a good choice)
  • password
  • database name (cloudcoderdb is a good choice)
  • hostname (localhost if you are running MySQL and the webapp on the same machine, which is recommended)
  • port number (3306 is the standard MySQL port)

The following commands assume we are configuring MySQL under Linux.

To create a MySQL user with the username cloudcoder and password somepassword, run the command

mysql --user=root --pass \
--execute="create user 'cloudcoder'@'localhost' identified by 'somepassword'"

Enter the password for the MySQL root user when prompted. Replace somepassword with the password you want to use. (If you chose a different username, replace cloudcoder with that username.)

Next, grant the cloudcoder user account permission to create the database:

mysql --user=root --pass \
--execute="grant all on cloudcoderdb.* to 'cloudcoder'@'localhost'"

Again, replace cloudcoder and cloudcoderdb with the username and database name you chose previously.
